author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**JonnyRhea**
@protolambda just saw this: https://notes.ethereum.org/9Ijj2RkuRiqQYB9NOfY_9Q  interesting idea.  how are u planning on testing/simulating this strategy to determine how effective it is in practice?

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**protolambda**
@JonnyRhea I am looking at different options. Jannik from Trinity had some gossipsub models, but they are not using a production implementation of gossipsub. Another option would be to mock a network around the Go or Python gossipsub implementation. Modelling the time component; no hardcoded sleep or tickers. (Go has a mocknet, but it doesn't model time). That way the model doesn't have to run in realtime, and is not so heavy on actual network overhead (just model delays). And bounded by memory. Then plug in the strategy ideas for dropping poor messages, and aggregating new ones. Discussed lots of things and variations around devcon and Taipei conference. Also talked with the Handel folks (what got this all started), and just want to give pubsub based attestations a try.

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**protolambda**
The cost function idea only helps optimize the aggregation choices, and can help in decision making for what to drop. Epidemically pulling enough messages off the network to warrant publishing new aggregations is difficult however, and certainly needs to be tested

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content: **JonnyRhea** (in reply to **protolambda**)

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content: i like the idea of mocking/simulating the network.  i was thinking that if we can structure the the gossipsub tests properly by identifying as many design variables as possible and doing parameter sweeps with a full factorial design matrix, then we could generate some valuable raw data that could be used to help design more accurate simulations.

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content: **shahankhatch** (in reply to **protolambda**)

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content: Thanks for the suggested approach to formalize a cost model for gossipsub. The reason why Handel's cost function makes sense is that it is based on incoming aggregations, and a single aggregation is forwarded (as defined by the tree-like structure). The incoming/outgoing graph structure is deterministic. I envision that validators will perhaps desire the flexibility of adopting different cost models depending on factors like network congestion, known validator connections, or rack-level knowledge. Perhaps I'm mistaken, but wouldn't a challenge with applying cost functions to a gossipsub approach, such to 'aggregate subtrees of equivalent size', require knowing the entire network structure ahead of time and what aggregations the other validators have actually received? Which means that as aggregations are being processed across the network? So, still working to be deterministic, but with less formal guarantess than a known expected structure. It also assumes that the cost function is applied uniformly across the network. fyi I'm not arguing for Handel's approach, as I think Handel's approach would be one of the cost functions and determistic network structures which could work in conjunction with a gossipsub approach.

author: .fjl
content: you can influence gossipsub to some degree by influencing which peers get pruned / grafted based on the cost function

author: .fjl
content: another question: doesn't any kind of pre-determined network structure throw out the idea of validator privacy?
